title: 108_s2298
content: The Employee Stock Ownership Plan Promotion and Improvement Act of 2004 may be cited as the Act. It pertains to distributions by an S Corporation to an Employee Stock Ownership Plan. The Employee Stock Ownership Plan Promotion and Improvement Act of 2004, also known as the Act, amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to treat distributions by an S Corporation to an Employee Stock Ownership Plan as dividends. The amendments apply to distributions received after December 31, 1998. The Act allows for refunds or credits of tax within a 1-year period from enactment, even if prevented by law, for distributions by an S Corporation to an Employee Stock Ownership Plan. The Act allows for refunds or credits of tax within a 1-year period from enactment for distributions by an S Corporation to an Employee Stock Ownership Plan, with an ESOP dividend exception to adjustments based on adjusted current earnings. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows for deductions on dividends paid to an ESOP established before March 15, 1991, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1989. Refunds or credits of tax resulting from this amendment can be claimed within a 1-year period from enactment. Refunds or credits of tax resulting from the amendment can be claimed within a 1-year period from enactment, even if prevented by law. SEC. 4. AMENDMENTS RELATED TO SECTION 1042. Amendments related to Section 1042 include deferral of tax for certain sales to an employee stock ownership plan sponsored by an S Corporation and reinvestment in certain mutual funds permitted. The effective date for the deferral of tax amendment is after the enactment of the Act. Financial institutions, insurance companies, and mutual funds are included in the definition of an operating corporation. The amendment in section 581 applies to sales of qualified securities after the enactment of the Act. There is a modification to the 25-percent shareholder rule in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a provision for the benefit of individuals owning more than 25% of the voting power or stock value of a corporation. The amendment is effective for sales of qualified securities after the enactment of the Act. The amendment made by paragraph (1) will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. Early distributions from employee stock ownership plans for higher education expenses and first-time homebuyer purchases. SEC. 5 amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow distributions from employee stock ownership plans for higher education expenses and first-time homebuyer purchases. The text discusses limitations on distributions from employee stock ownership plans for higher education expenses and first-time homebuyer purchases. Distributions must be reduced by certain expenses and qualified first-time homebuyer distributions. The distribution must be in the form of employer securities or cash proceeds. The text discusses limitations on distributions from employee stock ownership plans for higher education expenses and first-time homebuyer purchases. Distributions must be reduced by certain expenses and qualified first-time homebuyer distributions. The distribution must be in the form of employer securities or cash proceeds resulting from the sale of such securities made not more than 180 days before the date of distribution. Securities distributed or sold must be held for at least 5 years before distribution or sale. Conforming Amendments: Section 72(t) of the Code is amended to include subparagraphs (E) and (G) of paragraph (2). Paragraph (8) of section 72(t) of the Code is amended to include subparagraphs (F) and (G) of paragraph (2). The amendments apply to distributions made after the enactment of this Act.
